title: Coat of Arms
timelinePrompt: But back to our 4 languages challenge. Where in our timeline is this next image?
closelookingPrompt: This is a coat of arms from 1504. Take a closer look and find out who commissioned it.
closelookingAnswers: Sebastian vom Stein, Bailiff in Ticino, Massimiliano Sforza, Duke of Milan, Louis XII., King of France, Roger Federer, Swiss Tennis Legend
closelookingFeedback: Right! Sebastian vom Stein from Bern is 1513 appointed as the first bailiff in Ticino.
closelookingMoreInfo:
The majority of the population of Ticino is Italian-speaking. How did the area come to be annexed?

In the 14th and 15th centuries, the area that is now Ticino was under the rule of Como and Milan (Italy).  Various campaigns by the Confederates in the 15th century lead to the conquest of the northern border areas of the Duchy of Milan. It becomes a subject territory of the Confederation. With the Helvetic Republic 1798 Ticino becomes an equal canton.

title: Treaty of Stans
timelinePrompt: We know now when Italian became part of the Swiss Confederation. How was it with French? The next object will tell us more! Place it on the timeline!
timelineCorrectFeedback: Correct!!! French was even before italian!
closelookingPrompt: In 1481, the Confederates reaffirmed their old alliances. How many Old Cantons have sealed the treaty?
closelookingFeedback: Fantastic!!! Fribourg becomes part of the Confederation in 1481 as a French-speaking region, but is given fewer rights than the eight Old Cantons that seal the treaty.
closelookingMoreInfo: Until the collapse of the Old Swiss Confederacy in 1798, the German language became more and more widespread in Fribourg. After that, the language of the French-speaking majority becomes official again and in 1848, with the Federal Constitution, becomes an official language of equal value.

title: Romansch
timelinePrompt: Well, we got how German, French and Italian became official languages of Switzerland. But when did Romansch become official?
timelineCorrectFeedback: Exactly!! In 1938, Romansh was recognised as the fourth national language in a referendum. But where do they speak Romansch? Go to the 1900's room to find this map.
closelookingPrompt: Look closely at the single railroad line on the 5,2 square of this map. What’s the final city that the rail line travels to in that square?
closelookingFeedback: Good job!! Chur is the capital of the canton of Graubünden. Most people who can speak Romansh live in this canton.
closelookingMoreInfo:
In 2021, 13.9% of people in Graubünden state Romansh as their main language. This equates to around 40,000 people. A similar number to the capacity of the Basel football stadium. This map shows you where the Romanish get spoken. 

Due to the former remoteness of many places and valleys, 5 different idioms of Romansch have developed. Some of these language idioms are so different that two Romansh speakers cannot communicate with each other straight away. This is not surprising when you consider that some places are more than 4 hours away from each other when travelling.
